StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in ambient air samples collected from various areas in Stockholm, Sweden from June 1980 to Dec 1983 at mean concentrations of 0.3-4.2 ng/cu m(1). The mean indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentration in ambient air samples from Geulhaven, Schiedam, Lekhaven and Kralingen, The Netherlands were 2.39, 1.41, 1.58 and 1.40 ng/cu m, respectively(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in air samples from South Kensington, UK collected between Oct 1985 and Dec 1987 at concentrations of 0.21-3.43 ng/cu m for particulates collected 1985 to 1987(3). Yearly mean particulate phase indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations at an urban site in Lahore, Pakistan and Birmingham, UK were 12.31 and 1.19 ng/cu m, respectively(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in air samples collected along Exhibition Road, London Jan 1991 to July 1992 at <0.01-10.37 ng/cu m with an average of 2.58 ng/cu m(5). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in air in the particulate phase at 1.57 and 2.0 ng/cu m in South Kensington and Birmingham, UK, respectively(6). The mean particulate phase indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentration in 62 samples collected Sept 21, 1992 to Oct 1, 1993 in urban Lahore, Pakistan was 12.31 ng/cu m(7). Mean winter particulate phase indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations at an urban site in Lahore, Pakistan were 16.45 ng/cu m(7). Ambient air samples collected from Osaka, Japan in 1981 and 1982 contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 2.64-11.77 ng/cu m with an average of 6.08 ng/cu m(8). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was monitored before, during and after the summer Olympics in Beijing, China; concentrations were 609.9-3051.7, 587.1-4773.2, 609.9-1469.5, and 587.1-4772.3 pg/cu m in samples collected Jul 28-Sept 20, Sept 21-Oct 7, Aug 8-24, and July 28-Aug 7 plus Sept 26-Oct 7, 2008(9). The average concentration of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene in 11 atmospheric samples collected Mar-Nov 2002 from the city of Prato, Italy was 1.99 ng/cu m(10). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in urban aerosol samples collected in summer and winter from Augsburg, Germany at 0.18 and 2.66 ng/cu m, respectively(11).

StringWithMarkup.String: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected (detection limit 0.50 ug/kg) in food samples (cereals, meat, fish, oils and fats, fruits and sugar, root or other vegetables, beverages, milk) collected in the United Kingdom in 1979(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations in Canadian process cereals were, ug/kg: 3.0 (puffed wheat), 1.4 (wheat bran), and 0.2 (corn bran); in cooking oils, ug/kg: 0.5 (soy) and 0.5 (corn); and in barley malt 0.4 ug/kg(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in smoked whiting, Labrador fish and smoked oysters at 0.7, 1.1 and 1.3 ppb, respectively; Edam and cheddar cheeses at 0.7 and 0.3 ppb; sliced turkey at 0.4 ppb; sliced ham at 0.1 ppb; and beef franks at 0.3 ppb(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in mesquite grilled beef patties at 22, 20 and 15 ug/kg for 70% lean, 80% lean, and 90% lean beef, respectively, and at respective concentrations of 5, 4 ug/kg and not detected in hardwood charcoal grilled patties(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected in food products from 10 markets in 3 regions of Hong Kong, China (coconut milk, evaporated milk, goose liver, chicken skin, chicken breast, white and red wine, corn, mustard seed, olive, peanut, fish or flaxseed oil, flaxseed and fish oil capsules, pistachio, sunflower or pumpkin seed, Hawaii nutlet, almond, cashew, walnut or peanut) samples were collected Aug to Oct 2007(5).

Reference: (1) Speer K et al; J High Res Chromatogr 13: 104-111 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 0.14-0.72 ug/kg fresh weight in 23 lettuce (Lactuca sativa var. crispa) samples grown in private gardens Sept 1984 in southern Finland(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected in Finnish fat samples of margarine, sunflower oil, cold pressed sunflower oil, corn oil, olive oil, it was detected the following samples, ug/kg: 80% butter and vegetable oil mixture, 0.07; cooking margarines, 0.03-1.1; table margarines, not detected to 0.70; margarine, 5.3; cold pressed corn oil, 0.85; rapeseed and turnip rapeseed oil, 0.21; soybean oil, not detected to 0.30; and coconut fat, 0.02(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in 38 samples of margarine, 10 samples of mussels, 5 samples of spinach and 8 samples of kale at a mean concentration of 1.0, 4.1, 0.3 and 2.0 ug/kg, respectively(3). Samples of fish and shrimp purchased from local fish markets in Kuwait in May 1993 were found to contain indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at an average concentration of 5.63 ug/kg dry weight(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected in flowering Chinese cabbage (Brassica parachinensis), Chinese cabbage (Brassica chinensis), water spinach (Ipomoea aquatica), edible amaranth (Amaranthus tricolor), mustard (Brassica juncea), lettuce (Loctuca satira), asparagus bean (Vigna sesquipedalis), shallot (Allium ascalonicum), Chinese chive (Allium tuberosum), balpear (Momordica charantia) or cucumber (Cucumis sativus) samples collected from nine farms located in the Pearl River Delta, South China(5). Honey collected May-Oct 2007 from eight sample locations in Italy did not contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene (detection limit at 0.19 ng/g wet weight)(6).

Reference: (1) Janska M et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 77: 492-9 (2006)

StringWithMarkup.String: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in respective young and old leaves of beech at 38 and 234 ug/kg, oak at 26 and 150 ug/kg and tobacco at 18 and 38 ug/kg(1). Casuarina littorina (needles) collected near a roadside in Brisbane, Australia did not contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene; leaf litter collected from the same area contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 45 ng/g wet weight(2). In April 2005, pine needle samples were collected from 35 sites across Liaoning, China contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 2-9 ng/g dry weight(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in pine needle samples from 27 locations scattered all over the Portuguese continental territory at 0.7-7.9 and 0.6-9.5 ng/g dry weight in 19 Pinus pinea and 12 Pinus pinaster samples, respectively; samples were collected in April 2007(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in phytoplankton/seston from Bohai Bay, north China at 7.02 ng/g dry weight in samples collected May, June and Sept 2002(5). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in aquatic moss samples collected from the Danube and Traun rivers in Austria at 19-22 and 9.5-10 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(6). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 8-68 and <5-29 ng/g dry weight in moss species H. splendens and P. schreberi, respectively; samples were collected July 2005 from 10 locations in the southern part of the Holy Cross Mountains, Poland(7). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in moss samples from nine sites at 8.2-64 ng/g dry weight with a mean of 10.8 ng/g dry weight; samples were collected Sept 2005 from Wienerwald, Austria(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: Mussels (Mytilus edulis) from Yaquina Bay, OR contained indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 1.0-9.4 ug/kg wet weight (site proximal to industry) and 0.2-0.5 ug/kg wet weight at a remote site; samples were collected 1979-1980(1). StringWithMarkup.String: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene has been identified in crude oil from Qatar at 7.4 mg/kg(1). It was also detected in two samples of kerosene at  <2.0 and <0.30 ppm weight/volume; in new engine oil at 0.02 mg/kg; and in used crankcase oils at 0.2-89 mg/kg, the highest concentration was found in oil from a gasoline engine driven 610,000 km(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in new motor oil at 0.001-0.020 ug/g; in used motor oil from petrol vehicles, diesel vehicles, diesel lorries and diesel buses indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene concentrations were 2.1-12.5, 0.8-9.0, 0.06-0.28 and 0.07-0.25 ug/g, respectively(5). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in 95% lead-free gasoline and premium leaded gasoline at mean concentrations of 0.25 and 0.37 mg/L, respectively(6). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in coal tar film and bulk coal tar at <2500 mg/kg(7). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in oil collected from one of four Kuwait oil lakes in Sept 1992 at 19.5-20.0 mg/kg(8). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in coal tar at 8.0 ug/g(9). The mean concentration of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was 0.25 ppm in used lubricating oils from gasoline fueled vehicles(10).

StringWithMarkup.String: Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene has been detected in mainstream cigarette smoke (0.4-2.0 ug/100 cigarettes)(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in cigarette mainstream and sidestream smoke at 14.0 and 29.0 ug/g,  respectively(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was reported as a constitute of cigarette smoke(3). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in pig and cattle slurry taken from pits on farms located at Swiss Soil Monitoring Network sites at 2-7 and 2-15 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(4). Samples from 3 different compost piles in Switzerland were found to contain indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at a range of 62-216 ug/kg dry weight with a mean of 162.7 ug/kg dry weight(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene has been detected in combustion products from polyethylene and polypropylene(5). Treated wood utility poles and railway ties in lower mainland and Vancouver Island, BC, Canada were found to contain indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at 36 and 40 mg/kg wet weight, respectively; sampling was conducted in 1990 and 1991(6). Wet and dry deposition of indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was reported at 11-100 and 1.5-25 ng/sq m/day, respectively; study was conducted on Mazzorbetto Island in the northern part of the Venetian lagoon, May to Nov 2005(7). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in 17% of house hold dust samples collected Feb 29 to Apr 11, 2004 from 24 homes in Kuwait from detection limit to 88 ng/g dust(8). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was not detected in 30 dust samples taken from the kitchens that use wood, kerosene and butane gas cook systems(9). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected at 0.100-33.5 ug/g in vacuum cleaner dust samples collected Nov 2002 and Mar 2003 from 75 homes in Ottawa, ON, Canada(10). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in surface road dusts collected in various locations throughout Birmingham, UK and Lahore, Pakistan at 10.0-5500 ug/kg(11).

StringWithMarkup.String: Occupational exposure may be through inhalation and dermal contact with indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene at workplaces where coal and petroleum derived substances are produced or used or where combustion processes are extensive(1). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in breathing zones of a plant producing carbon anodes for aluminum electrolysis at 0.11-3.99 ug/cu m(2). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene has been detected in occupational environments at the following airborne concentrations (geometric mean), ug/cu m: coke plant, 3.83; carbon anode plant, 0.817; graphite plant, 0.033; silicon carbide plant, 0.018; metal recycling plant, 0.044; and a bitumen paving plant, 0.003(3). Air samples collected above the doors of smoking kilns used in Danish smokehouses did not contain indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene (detection limit 0.2 ug/cu m)(4). Indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene was detected in the air of upper and lower floors of a Swedish alloy factory at an average of 94 and 43 ng/sample in samples collected Nov-Dec 2007 and at 80 and 91 ng/sample in samples collected Jan 2008(5). The general population may be exposed to indeno(1,2,3-cd)pyrene primarily through the smoking of tobacco, inhalation of polluted air and by ingestion of food(1).

A distinguishing feature of this effort is the accurate mapping of bioassay and physicochemical property data associated with chemical substances to their corresponding chemical structures.

Section.TOCHeading: International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) Classification
Section.Description: In the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classification, chemicals are categorized into four groups: Group 1 (carcinogenic to humans), Group 2A (probably carcinogenic to humans), Group 2B (possibly carcinogenic to humans), and Group 3 (not classifiable as to its carcinogenicity to humans).

EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.

Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign compounds to structural classes, currently mapped to >1.7 million per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from the datasets explained in Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A

Reference.Name: INDENO(1,2,3-CD)PYRENE
Reference.Description: CAMEO Chemicals is a chemical database designed for people who are involved in hazardous material incident response and planning. CAMEO Chemicals contains a library with thousands of datasheets containing response-related information and recommendations for hazardous materials that are commonly transported, used, or stored in the United States.
